results.title: Max Ernst
results.creator_credit: Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen, RM Arts and Peter Schamoni
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Traces the history of renowned painter and sculptor, Max Ernst, his personal life as well as artistic career. The program contains extensive interviews and commentary from Ernst himself which details the pattern of his life and work from his founding influence in the Surrealist movement, throughout World War II and his struggles within and without Germany up to his settlement in America and then move back to Europe. Opening with an outline of the commencement of the Dada movement in 1919, the program discusses the life history of Ernst from his move to Paris before World War II and his association and friendship with Paul Eluard along with other founding members of the Surrealist group. The details of his artistic interests in natural history made strange, that is, the confusion of disparate beings and objects in nature through mind and poetic associations, are discussed in terms of his public work as well as that undertaken in more personal spaces such as murals in friends houses and sculptures and exterior murals adorning his own various residences. With the advent of Hitler’s power in Germany, his works as a mirror to a ‘mad time’ are studied, along with the progress of Ernst away from the Surrealist movement before World War II. At the commencement of the war, a trying era began for Ernst of imprisonments at various stages in France for his German citizenship and as a result of false accusations, spending a few months in a concentration camp, which led to his subsequent difficult, but finally successful move to America with the help of colleague and third wife Peggy Guggenheim and the New York art scene. Here the program details his first Surrealist Exhibition in New York and his invention of what is now known as action painting, all received with great critical acclaim, and his following career in New York, during which time he married the painter, Dorothea Tanning. Their move to Arizona, to live and work in a ‘landscape of the minds eye’ signalled a time of detachment from many of his peers and a fascination with Native American culture and crafts and the rythms of the landscape that he had painted before seeing and that manifested a great influence in his works of the time. In the 1950s, his return to Europe was met with little recognition, but following the receipt of the Grand Prix of Venice in 1954, his acclaim saw an establishment of his freedom to experiment with his progression of interests in painting and sculpture once again. The program closes with an analysis of his work at this stage where his final settlement in the ‘Garden of France’ with Dorothea is discussed with reference to the hopeful nuances of his later series of paintings that studied the idea of the cage, and most symbolically, an empty cage from which a bird had escaped.

results.title: Max's money troubles
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Australia. Department of the Attorney-General, Timothy Read and Chris Adshead
results.brief_description: A humorous dramatisation about the implications of declaring oneself bankrupt. Max is an ordinary family man, who is in deep financial difficulty. His debts far exceed his ability to pay. We follow Max through the steps he must take to solve his seemingly unsolvable problem. He appears to find an ideal expedient in declaring himself bankrupt, but through counselling Max learns of the likely consequences of this and that it should only ever be a last resort. Written by Donald Crombie.

results.title: Max's Farm
results.brief_description: Max is a perfectionist. He loves his farm and wants it to be the best. The ‘Farmer’s Weekly’ arrives and his farm rates 27th. That’s a great score, but Max wants it number 1. He tries to improve his farm by eliminating what he thinks are pests, but that just makes his farm worse. He has to find out how to get things work together.

results.title: Max's Christmas and 3 other Christmas stories
results.brief_description: Max’s Christmas It’s Christmas Eve and Max is too excited to go to sleep, so he sneaks downstairs to await Santa’s arrival … “Morris’s disappearing bag” Morris, the youngest child, is ignored on Christams morning until he discovers an overlooked present - a disappearing bag! These two stories are adapted from books by Rosemary Wells. “The Clown of God” Tomie de Paola’s classic picture book of the juggler who is too poor to give a gift to the Christ child. “The Little drummer boy” Joyful drumming, glowing illustrations and the voices of the St. Paul Choir School bring this well-known Christmas story to life. Illustrations by Ezra Jack Keats. Each of these stories is also available as an individual title.

results.title: Mawson Base: face to face
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Education Dept. Materials Production, Ivan Gaal, Rob McCubbin and Ian Toohill
results.brief_description: Shot mainly around the Mawson area and narrated by Dr Phillip Law, this film looks at Antartica through the eyes of the expedition’s cook and the doctor. Raises issues on the future of Antartica and gives insight into the daily pressures of life in isolation. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Mavis goes to Timor
results.creator_credit: December Films, Tony Wright, Stuart Menzies, Steve Westh and Catherine Marciniak
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Grey voyagers”.
86 year old Mavis Taylor travels from Yarrawonga to East Timor on her first trip overseas. Against the odds, she plans to establish a sewing co-operative for the local women. Frustrated by bureaucracy, Mavis seeks assistance from the local community to help her transform an abandoned hospital into a warehouse and training centre for the co-operative. Her determination and perseverance is rewarded when the first order arrives and a group of local women are trained and organised to meet the delivery deadline. The project provides an opportunity for the women to establish economic security and independence for themselves and their community. During her stay in East Timor, Mavis also visits a church whose congregation was massacred by the Indonesian militia. Cinematography by Catherine Marciniak. Edited by Andrea Lang. Narrated by Anne Phelan.

results.title: Mauve Desert
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: As you drive Mauve Desert I hope you keep in mind where you sit and what drives you to understanding.’ This a story about Melanie, a fifteen year-old, who steals her mother’s car and drives into the desert. How she feels about herself and the process of becoming is echoed by her spoken thoughts on the desert landscape she drives through. Low-resolution graphics and a distinctive design style support the raw, and grungy atmosphere of Melanie’s world. The main interface is a map. The map promises adventure and danger, hinted at by the areas of the map lighting up. The offscreen sounds include dogs barking, gunshots and a car engine turning over. The narrative structure of Mauve Desert makes the user get stuck at certain points. We can only sit back and watch. Sometimes an area is available to click on, sometimes that area will not respond, encouraging the user to be opportunistic in future encounters. Different pieces of video will be produced at particular intervals, suggesting that an underlying logic holds the project together. The theme of understanding and interpretation is also reflected in the layers within the project where fact is merged with fiction. There is Maude Laures, the academic, who stumbles upon Melanie’s life in a second-hand bookshop. The project is based on the novel Le Desert Mauve by QuebeÃ½oise author Nicole Brossard,Mauve Desert’.

The map promises adventure and danger, hinted at by the areas of the map lighting up. The offscreen sounds include dogs barking, gunshots and a car engine turning over. The narrative structure of Mauve Desert makes the user get stuck at certain points. We can only sit back and watch. Sometimes an area is available to click on, sometimes that area will not respond, encouraging the user to be opportunistic in future encounters. Different pieces of video will be produced at particular intervals, suggesting that an underlying logic holds the project together. The theme of understanding and interpretation is also reflected in the layers within the project where fact is merged with fiction. There is Maude Laures, the academic, who stumbles upon Melanie’s life in a second-hand bookshop. The project is based on the novel Le Desert Mauve by QuebeÃ½oise author Nicole Brossard,Mauve Desert’.
description_for_label: As you drive Mauve Desert I hope you keep in mind where you sit and what drives you to understanding.’ This a story about Melanie, a fifteen year-old, who steals her mother’s car and drives into the desert. How she feels about herself and the process of becoming is echoed by her spoken thoughts on the desert landscape she drives through. Low-resolution graphics and a distinctive design style support the raw, and grungy atmosphere of Melanie’s world. The main interface is a map. The map promises adventure and danger, hinted at by the areas of the map lighting up. The offscreen sounds include dogs barking, gunshots and a car engine turning over. The narrative structure of Mauve Desert makes the user get stuck at certain points. We can only sit back and watch. Sometimes an area is available to click on, sometimes that area will not respond, encouraging the user to be opportunistic in future encounters. Different pieces of video will be produced at particular intervals, suggesting that an underlying logic holds the project together. The theme of understanding and interpretation is also reflected in the layers within the project where fact is merged with fiction. There is Maude Laures, the academic, who stumbles upon Melanie’s life in a second-hand bookshop. The project is based on the novel Le Desert Mauve by QuebeÃ½oise author Nicole Brossard,Mauve Desert’.

details.label: Materials

results.title: Mauvais Sang = Bad Blood
results.creator_credit: Alain Dahan, Philippe Diaz and Leos Carax
results.brief_description:
Alex’s father, an old ganster, has just died. For old time’s sake, Alex asks two former accomplices of his father to organise one last robbery. The target is a new antidote designed to fight a virus called STBO. STBO is spread by having impersonal sex and is killing adolescents by the score. With ‘Mauvais Sang’ (his second film), Leos Carax finds his way into an esthetic movement of French cinema emerging in the 1980’s as ‘neo-baroque’ (aka ‘cinema du look’). Just like Luc Besson and Jean-Jacques Beineix, Carax favours outrageous lighting effects, a very pronounced acting style and a fetishist usage of objects. Awards: Prix Louis Delluc, 1986.

Credits: Producers, Alain Dahan, Philippe Diaz ; director, Leos Carax ; writer, Leos Carax ; photography, Jean-Yves Escoffier ; music, Charlie Chaplin, Sergei Prokofiev, Benjamin Britten.
Cast: Denis Lavant, Juliette Binoche, Michel Piccoli, Hans Meyer, Julie Delpy, Hugo Pratt, Serge Reggiani, Mireille Perrier, Jerome Zucca.
